Software that suggests job profiles based on parsed experience and qualifications, ats compatibility for their profile and an auto content resume analysis for the users.the technology gives hr professionals the ability to process resumes in bulk and generate rankings of the top candidates for specific job roles, in addition to providing tools for creating and monitoring job ads.
As per trialworks, after thorough testing and evaluation, the technology was able to match people with suitable jobs about 67% of the time.
It also sets the stage for smarter job-matching algorithms that can significantly cut down hiring time and improve the overall quality of candidates being selected.

To address some of those, this project introduces an intelligent resume screening system that uses ai and machine learning to improve how resumes are processed.rather than depending completely on manual resume checks, this approach streamlines the process by making it faster and more precise, while also helping to reduce bias.
It makes use of advanced technologies like automated document processing and natural language understanding to create a real- world, useful solution.
From small startups to large corporations.
1.2 background of the problem with the rise of digital accessibility and the rapid evolution of the job market, companies today are dealing with a massive increase in job applications.
On average, hr teams spend nearly a quarter of their time—around 23%—just reviewing resumes.
For large organizations, a single job posting might attract thousands of applications, making it incredibly tough to manage such high volumes efficiently.
Manual screening isn't just time-consuming—it’s also vulnerable to human error and unconscious bias.
Inconsistencies between how different recruiters assess resumes only make the problem worse, often delaying hiring decisions and slowing down company growth.
On top of that, long hiring cycles drive up costs and make it harder to track and analyze important recruitment data.
While applicant tracking systems (ats) were introduced to ease some of these problems, most still rely heavily on basic keyword searches.
These systems often miss out on strong candidates who have the right skills but don’t use the exact keywords in their resumes.
Over the past few decades, the hiring process has transformed—from paper resumes to powerful digital platforms that process thousands of applications every day.
The time spent by recruiters manually reviewing resumes not only adds cost but can also lead to losing top talent to faster-moving competitors.
Xi human bias further complicates things.

Studies have shown that decisions made during manual screening can be affected by subconscious factors—like favoring candidates who seem similar to the reviewer or confirming assumptions based on limited information.
While tools like ats help filter resumes, many still fall short in truly understanding the context of a candidate’s experience.

That’s why there’s a growing need for smarter, more accurate solutions—ones that go beyond simple filters and actually understand the deeper match between a candidate’s qualifications and a role’s real needs.
Most hr teams spend way too many hours manually going through resumes.
The longer the process drags out, the more it holds back progress for everyone involved.
Teams can’t move forward, projects get delayed, and the business feels the impact.
Human bias—whether we admit it or not—has a way of creeping into decisions.
Maybe one’s focused on job titles, another on education, or even something as minor as formatting.
They struggle with different resume formats or don’t pick up the right information.
Even when automation is in place, it's often not smart enough to really understand what a candidate brings to the table.
That means bad matches, wasted interviews, and a lot of missed opportunities.
But honestly, even many of the newer systems aren’t as effective as they should be.
They might scan resumes faster, but they often just look for exact keyword matches.
That lack of transparency makes it hard for recruiters to trust the process—and it’s even more frustrating for job seekers who never find out what went wrong or how to improve.
On top of that, most platforms focus only on one side of the hiring equation.
Either they’re built for employers, or they’re made to help candidates.
A smarter, more balanced system.
This technology also aims to address the pressing need to reduce bias in hiring procedures.
The emergence of sophisticated natural language processing (nlp) capabilities and improvements in machine learning algorithms create opportunities for more effective and efficient resume screening.
By making the recruitment process more efficient and cutting down on the time it takes to hire, the tool helps organizations use their resources more effectively.
Not only does it help find better candidates, but the improved quality of hires can lead to stronger employee performance and higher retention rates.

On top of that, a smoother and more positive candidate experience helps build a good reputation for the company, strengthening its brand in the long run. 1.5 project scope this project isn’t just about building a tool—it’s about pulling together everything needed to make the resume screening process smarter and more practical.

The system’s designed to handle a range of tasks, like going through resumes automatically, picking out the important bits, building up profiles for each applicant, xiii and checking how well they match up with what a job actually needs.
It also sorts and ranks candidates and puts together reports that help recruiters make better, faster decisions.
On the tech side, we’re looking at putting together a web-based platform that’s easy to access and use.
A solid database will sit behind it to store everything properly, and the system will be built to connect smoothly with other tools via apis.
Since we’ll be dealing with personal data, making sure everything is secure is also a top priority.
The target user groups for this system include hr professionals, hiring managers, and system administrators.

Each user group will benefit from the system's functionality in streamlining and automating various recruitment tasks, making the hiring process more efficient and accurate.the scope of this research encompasses the design, implementation, and testing of a web-based resume parsing and job recommendation system with dual user interfaces.
It includes the creation of custom natural language processing algorithms for resume parsing and semantic matching between candidate qualifications and job requirements.
The work also involves performance evaluation through assessment of system accuracy, efficiency, and user satisfaction through controlled testing scenarios.

The initial system focuses on technical and professional fields where skills and qualifications can be more objectively quantified, with plans for expansion to additional industries in subsequent phases.

From a theoretical perspective, it advances understanding of semantic analysis techniques applicable to unstructured document parsing, develops new models for quantifying the relationship between candidate qualifications and job requirements, and establishes methodologies for evaluating the accuracy of automated candidate selection systems. in practical terms, the system provides a functioning solution that reduces resume screening time by an estimated 60-70%, improves candidate selection quality through more comprehensive qualification analysis, assists job seekers in understanding their marketability and targeting appropriate positions, and enables hr professionals to process larger candidate pools without increasing resource allocation.

The economic implications include potential reduction in time-to-hire metrics by 30- 45%, decreased cost-per-hire through process optimization, and improved quality- of-hire metrics through better candidate-job matching.
These benefits collectively xiv address critical inefficiencies in current recruitment practices while establishing a foundation for further advancement in intelligent recruitment systems.
Instead than employing a human method to sort through stacks of resumes, automation could save time and effort.
Ultimately, it suggests that companies may find the right people faster and make better hiring decisions overall.
1.6.2 business value its business value stems from its ability to reduce time-to-hire and recruitment costs, two aspects that instantly improve organizational effectiveness.
Organizations benefit in the long run from increased staff retention and performance.
1.6.3 social impact more generally, the approach can help combat hiring bias by creating an even playing field for all applicants.
By expediting the hiring process, businesses may find the best fit faster and boost their ability to support a more efficient labor market.
The solution also improves the entire candidate experience by making the hiring process faster and more open.

Xv chapter 2: literature review 2.1 evolution of recruitment technology you know, recruitment tech has come a long way, and it really reflects bigger changes in how companies manage their teams and use technology overall.
Back in the day, before everything got digital, hiring was super manual.
Recruiters dealt with paper resumes, face-to-face interviews, and ads in newspapers — basically, a lot of legwork and time spent going through piles of applications.
Things started shifting in the late ’90s when the first applicant tracking systems showed up.
But honestly, those early systems were pretty basic.
They mostly helped store resumes electronically, but they didn’t really make hiring decisions any smarter.
Manual hiring had its own set of headaches.
When digital tools first arrived, they let companies store applications electronically and do some basic filtering.
First, it was mostly about building big resume databases with little processing power.
Finally, ai started creeping in, with simple natural language processing and machine learning to better analyze resumes.
Still, many early digital tools just digitized the same old problems — bias and shallow understanding of a candidate’s real qualifications.
Some tools stick to traditional applicant tracking — managing workflows and simple filters.
Others use ai to predict fit based on hiring history.
There are platforms that skip resumes altogether, focusing on skills tests instead.
And then, there are big talent suites that do it all — parsing resumes, managing interviews, and keeping candidates engaged.
Machines still struggle to fully understand a person’s qualifications in the right context or match them reliably to jobs.
There’s still a lot of room for making hiring smarter and fairer.
2.2 resume parsing technologies parsing resumes is basically a niche part of natural language processing that deals with the tricky stuff resumes throw at us.
Unlike neat, standardized forms, resumes come in all shapes and sizes.
They don’t follow one fixed pattern—different people organize their info differently, use varied section titles, and format everything in their xvi own way.
Then there’s all the professional jargon, abbreviations, and terms specific to certain fields.
One way is rule-based systems.
They usually get about 65-75% accuracy but can struggle when the resume looks unusual or doesn’t fit common formats.
These models do a better job, often reaching 83-88% accuracy on benchmark tests.

The extraction of structured information from unstructured or semi-structured resume documents presents unique challenges, with critical extraction targets including contact information, educational background, employment history, skills and competencies, certifications and credentials, and projects and achievements.

Recent advancements in named entity recognition and relationship extraction have improved extraction accuracy, with transformer-based models pre-trained on domain-specific corpora achieving 92% accuracy in identifying educational institutions and degrees, while employment history extraction reached 87% accuracy for position titles and organizations.

The relationship between extraction accuracy and downstream matching performance remains an active research area, with a strong correlation established between parsing accuracy and subsequent job matching quality, emphasizing the critical importance of high-quality information extraction as a foundation for recommendation systems.

2.3 job recommendation algorithms you know, automatically matching candidates to jobs isn’t just about algorithms— it’s actually quite different from the usual recommendation systems you see on shopping sites or streaming platforms.
So these systems have to be way more accurate than just recommending a movie or a product.

Another tricky part is that feedback is harder to come by—unlike consumer apps where people click and rate instantly, in recruitment, you get much less feedback and it often comes late, which makes fine-tuning the system a challenge.

Plus, it’s not just about what the candidate wants or what the employer wants separately; the system needs to xvii juggle both at once, and on top of that, it has to make sure it’s fair and doesn’t discriminate.
Researchers have tried out a few main ways to do candidate-job matching.
One common method is content-based filtering, where the system looks for similarities between a candidate’s profile and the job requirements.
Some fancy versions of this can actually understand meaning better than just matching keywords, improving accuracy by about 27%.
Then there’s collaborative filtering, which basically says, “hey, candidates like you applied to these jobs, so you might like these too.”
But this runs into problems when the job or candidate is new and there’s no history—this is called the “cold start” issue.
Another approach is knowledge-based systems, which use expert rules or structured info to guide matches.
Finally, hybrid systems combine several approaches, and these tend to do the best overall because they balance out the weaknesses of each method.
Instead of just spotting exact skill names, the system tries to recognize when different words mean the same thing or infer what someone can actually do based on their job descriptions.
This has helped improve match accuracy by around 31%.
Measuring how good these systems are is a bit complicated.

So researchers also look at things like how well the candidate’s qualifications line up with the job, whether the recommendations are diverse enough (to avoid always suggesting the same types of people), if the system treats everyone fairly across different groups, and how well it can explain why it made certain recommendations.
One big challenge is balancing accuracy with diversity.

If the system just tries to find the “perfect match,” it might end up recommending only a very narrow group of candidates, missing out on people with different but valuable skills.. 2.4 performance evaluation in recruitment systems requires specialized recruitment system effectiveness the assessment of methodologies addressing the unique characteristics of the domain.
Measuring the accuracy of recruitment systems presents significant challenges due to the subjective nature of "correct" matches and the delayed nature of outcome feedback.

Comprehensive accuracy evaluation frameworks incorporate expert validation through comparison of system recommendations with those of experienced recruiters; outcome tracking through longitudinal assessment of candidate success in recommended positions; and comparative ranking through evaluation of system- generated rankings against manually created rankings.
Expert validation provides the most immediately actionable feedback, while outcome tracking offers the most definitive but significantly delayed assessment of recommendation quality.

Industry accuracy baselines have been established with basic ats systems showing 47-58% agreement with expert recruiters, mid-tier intelligent systems achieving 59- 71% agreement, and advanced ai-driven platforms reaching 72-85% agreement.

Xviii these benchmarks provide context for evaluating the 67% accuracy achieved by the system developed in this research. beyond accuracy, recruitment systems must demonstrate operational efficiency and scalability to provide practical value, with key performance indicators including processing throughput (number of resumes processable per time unit), response latency (time required to analyze individual documents), scaling efficiency (performance degradation under increasing load), and resource utilization (computational resources required per processed document).
The ultimate success of recruitment systems depends on user satisfaction across multiple dimensions, with distinct satisfaction components for each user category.
Job seekers value recommendation relevance, discovery of previously unknown opportunities, transparency of qualification assessment, and actionable improvement guidance.

Systems providing clear explanations for recommendations achieve significantly higher user satisfaction rates regardless of actual match quality, highlighting the importance of transparency in building user trust.

Xix chapter 3: requirement analysis and system specification the feasibility study for the intelligent resume screening tool has key dimensions: technical feasibility, economic feasibility, operational feasibility, data requirements, functional requirements, performance requirements, and security requirements.

3.1 techincal feasibility given the availability of necessary technologies like python for backend processing, libraries for natural language processing, and contemporary web frameworks, the system has a high technical feasibility.
The system simply needs moderate processing power and is made to be installed on common cloud infrastructure.

Long-term cost reductions will result from the system's ability to automate the resume screening process, which will enable recruiting decisions to be made more quickly and require fewer human resources for manual resume evaluation.
3.3 operational feasibility operational viability indicates that the tool's user-friendly design and significant time savings will make it very acceptable to hr professionals.
The system's architecture guarantees that it will be simple to use, and hr teams will quickly recognize the efficiency it offers in processing resumes.
It should make detailed reports and give some good stats.
It needs to rank candidates by how good a fit they are, match their skills to job needs, and automatically pull info from resumes.
3.6 performance requirements the system must let a bunch of users work at once without slowing down.
The system has to use role-based controls, so folks only see what’s allowed.

The interface should look nice, be easy to use, and work well on phones, tablets, and pcs.. xxi chapter 4: system design so basically, this tool — the intelligent resume screening thing — was built to be kinda flexible.

There’s a resume parser (that breaks down resumes), candidate profile part (holds the info), job requirement stuff (job needs), and the matching engine — that’s the part that tries to figure out which people fit which jobs.
They’ve got some flow diagrams — you know, to show what happens first, then next, and so on.
Like: upload resume → system looks at it → matches it to job → gives result.
On the database end, it uses mysql.
They made sure to organize the data
Well so there’s no messy duplication — using something called 3nf (third normal form).
Also, for performance and security, they used some solid stuff — like connection pooling and prepared statements.

The system makes use of design patterns like the repository pattern for data access, the strategy pattern for matching algorithms, the observer pattern for status updates, and the factory pattern for document processors.

Xxii data flow diagram xxiii user flow diagram xxiv chapter 5: implementation, testing, and maintenance the implementation phase makes use of modern technologies and development practices to ensure robust functionality.in backend development python, , with libraries such as spacy, nltk, and tensorflow for nlp and machine learning.
State management is handled using redux, ensuring predictable application behaviour.
Version control is managed through git with a feature branch workflow, and code reviews are conducted regularly to maintain code quality.
Key milestones include the development of the core parser, matching engine implementation, user interface design, testing, optimization, and deployment.

Testing strategies include unit testing using pytest for the backend, jest for the frontend, integration testing using postman for api endpoints, system testing with end-to-end scenarios, user acceptance testing (hr feedback), and performance testing with apache jmeter.
Automated test scripts are written to cover edge cases and ensure system reliability.

Xxv dashboard xxvi sign up sign in and sign up is done using oauth and firebase xxvii sign in xxviii hr dashboard xxix about us xxx contact us xxxi chapter 6: results and discussions 6.1 system performance results the implemented resume parsing and job recommendation system demonstrated strong performance across multiple evaluation dimensions.
The resume parsing component achieved an overall information extraction accuracy of 86% when compared with manually labeled test data.

This accuracy varied by information category, with highest performance in structured elements such as contact information (94%) and education details (91%), while more complex elements such as skill extraction (82%) and responsibility identification (78%) showed lower but still robust accuracy.
These parsing results compare favorably with industry benchmarks and provide a solid foundation for subsequent matching operations.
On average, it took about 2.4 seconds to process each resume — and when running a batch of 100 resumes all at once, the whole thing wrapped up in roughly 95 seconds.
Even when a lot of users were on at the same time — up to 500 people — the performance stayed pretty steady.
There were no major slowdowns, which is a good sign.
Now about how well the system matches candidates to jobs — the algorithm managed to hit its target.
That’s a noticeable jump compared to simple keyword-matching methods and puts this tool somewhere in the middle tier when it comes to intelligent screening tools.
The ats compatibility score was particularly valued, with many users expressing surprise at specific formatting issues that could potentially limit their visibility in automated screening systems.
Job recommendations received moderately positive feedback, with 76% of users finding at least some of the suggested positions relevant to their qualifications and interests.
Users particularly appreciated the explanation of matching factors and qualification gaps, which provided actionable insights for career development.

The candidate ranking functionality received more varied feedback, with most users (78%) finding the top recommendations generally aligned with their professional judgment, while some expressed concerns about over-reliance on technical qualification matching at the expense of cultural fit and soft skills assessment.

However, the transparent explanation of ranking factors was universally appreciated, as it allowed recruiters to understand the basis for recommendations and apply their own judgment where appropriate.
The dual-interface approach proved effective, with both user categories successfully completing core tasks with minimal assistance after brief orientation.

User feedback led to several interface refinements during the testing phase, particularly regarding the presentation of complex information such as qualification gap analysis and candidate comparison views.
For individual job seekers, the system provided valuable insights into their professional presentation and marketability.

Users reported making specific improvements to their resumes based on system feedback, with 72% indicating they had reformatted their documents to improve ats compatibility and 64% adding specific skills or experiences highlighted as relevant by the recommendation engine.

The job discovery functionality expanded awareness of relevant opportunities, with 43% of users applying for positions they had not previously considered but were identified as good matches by the system.
For hr professionals and organizations, the efficiency gains were substantial.

The quality of shortlisted candidates improved according to 76% of hr users, who reported that system recommendations included qualified individuals who might have been overlooked in manual screening due to non-standard career paths or non-traditional qualification descriptions.

This unified approach improved alignment between candidate presentation and evaluation criteria, helping job seekers understand how their qualifications are perceived and evaluated by xxxiii automated systems increasingly used in initial screening.
The transparency of the matching process on both sides of the recruitment equation fostered more informed decision-making and realistic expectations from all participants.
People want to make their resumes stand out, which is great, but for this system?
That just makes things tricky.
Basically, there’s a balance between making a resume look cool and making sure the computer can actually understand it.
Then, there’s the matching part.
And honestly, that’s tough even for humans to judge, so it’s no surprise the system isn’t perfect at it.
Human recruiters often get those vibes during interviews or from their experience, but the tech can’t quite read between the lines yet.
People who’ve used this tool gave some good feedback too.
Job seekers want more ways to filter jobs — stuff like remote work or opportunities for moving up the ladder.
So, all in all, the system speeds things up a lot, but it’s not ready to replace the human touch when it comes to really understanding people.
It gets things right about two-thirds of the time, which is pretty good but not enough to just leave everything to machines.
People still gotta make the final call.
So, the sweet spot seems to be using ai to help out, but humans still in the driver’s seat.
That’d make matching way better.
Plus, if it got smarter at understanding xxxiv what people mean, not just what they say outright, that’d be huge.
And it’d be nice if companies could set their own rules on what matters most when picking people because every company’s different.
It could help schedule interviews, manage tests, even help onboard new hires.
That’d make it way more useful all- around.
Xxxv chapter 7: conclusion and future scope 7.1 summary of findings building and testing this resume parsing and job recommendation system taught us a lot about how smart tech fits into hiring.
The resume parser did a solid job pulling info from all kinds of messy resumes by mixing machine learning with some rule-based tricks.
The matching part hit about 67% accuracy compared to expert recruiters.
That’s decent—good enough to help, but not enough to ditch human judgement completely.
Performance tests showed the system runs smoothly without eating up too many resources.
They gave some ideas to make the interface better, but mostly they were happy with how it works. in real use, the system saved recruiters time and gave job seekers useful tips.
It also helped make sure candidates and job openings matched better.

So, smart hiring tools like this could fix a lot of problems in recruiting and help everyone involved. 7.2 theoretical and practical contributions this study contributes in a number of ways to the theoretical knowledge and real- world implementation of recruitment technology.

From a theoretical standpoint, the work develops methods that strike a balance between the flexibility of machine learning techniques and the accuracy of rule-based processing, thereby expanding our understanding of document comprehension strategies relevant to semi- structured professional papers.

The algorithm's implementation of a domain- specific strategy that tackles the distinct features of recruitment matching, such as asymmetric information needs, delayed feedback cycles, and multi-dimensional qualification evaluation, adds to the theory of recommendation systems.

A major strength of this project lies in the actual system that’s been developed — it’s not just theoretical but something that genuinely improves how resumes are screened and how candidates are matched to jobs.
What’s also important is the transparency in how the system explains its decisions — whether it's about how it parsed a resume or why it matched a candidate to a particular role.
This kind of openness helps people trust the process while still keeping the final say in human hands.
Xxxvi besides making things more efficient, the system could actually reduce recruitment costs over time.
But it doesn’t stop there — it also gives meaningful feedback by pointing out where a candidate might be falling short, along with practical suggestions for improvement.
7.3 limitations and future research despite having accomplished its main goals, the system has a number of drawbacks that impact its current use and suggest areas for further study.
Overall, the parsing accuracy was high, although it varied according on the document format and type of material, with really creative or unconventional layouts posing special difficulties.

Future studies should examine more reliable methods for identifying structures that preserve truth in a variety of visual presentations while upholding the crucial function of artistic self-expression in formal documents.

The matching algorithm's poorer performance for roles that prioritise soft skills and cultural considerations emphasises the need for better methods to assess these crucial but less obvious credentials.
The current implementation of the system concentrates on documents in english that are mainly found in technical and professional fields.

In order to support increasingly global recruitment operations, further research should examine domain adaptation strategies to improve performance across a range of industries and organisational contexts, as well as cross-linguistic parsing and matching.

Other intriguing directions include integrating data from sources other than resumes, such as project portfolios, professional activity data, and demonstrated abilities from several platforms to produce more thorough candidate profiles.

In addition to the expert comparison method now used, longitudinal studies that monitor recommendation quality against future employee performance would offer important confirmation of matching success.

These investigations could reveal patterns of qualification that are especially predictive and guide further optimisation of matching algorithms to better match long-term performance metrics instead of only initial screening decisions.

7.4 concluding remarks the resume parsing and job recommendation system serves as an example of the substantial potential of intelligent technology to improve hiring procedures for both individuals and businesses.

By attaining 67% candidate-job matching accuracy and xxxvii offering significant efficiency gains, the system validates the feasibility of ai- supported methods in this field while recognising the ongoing significance of human judgement in ultimate selection choices.
By meeting the interrelated demands of many players in the recruiting ecosystem, the dual-service approach improves alignment between evaluation criteria and candidate presentation and adds value.
Because of that, smarter ways to connect employers and job seekers are becoming super important.
This study tries to help with that, by actually making and testing a working system that deals with the problems we see today.
The research suggests that future hiring tech won’t just speed up old methods or replace humans.
What’s key here is balance.
You need to mix technology with human judgment.
It’s not just about being faster, but making smarter choices.
Keeping that balance in mind is really important if recruitment tools are going to be useful and make a difference — now and in the future.

Coding proficiency in at least one modern programming language (Python, Ruby, Java, etc)

Amazon.com strives to be Earth's most customer-centric company where people can find and discover virtually anything they want to buy online. By giving customers more of what they want - low prices, vast selection, and convenience - Amazon.com continues to grow and evolve as a world-class e-commerce platform. As an extension of this, Amazon encourages sellers/vendors to offer products to Amazon customers through various advertising. The Advertiser Success team is a support function to the local sales and account management teams and helps provide scale to add new participants and help them engage effectively with the ad programs. We work on various ad programs covering NA, EU and APAC markets and we provide 24/7 coverage for operations.

Advertiser Success team (AST) is looking for a talented and driven Data Engineer to scale our existing programs and power rapid innovation to empower us to stay ahead of our customers’ needs. Amazon is investing heavily in building a world class advertising business and the Advertising Sales Tech team is at the head of this growth machine enabling our Sales teams to deliver at scale. Our goal is to accelerate the otherwise human intensive sales operations by investing in strategic self-service applications that accelerate productivity of external advertising customers and internal sales executives. If executed correctly, we will minimize or eliminate the human decision making in advertising. The role will focus on working with a team of data engineers, business and tech savvy professionals to lay down scalable data architecture to ingest large amounts of structured and unstructured datasets and work with stakeholders to drive business decisions based on these datasets. Your opportunity is to apply technical abilities to work on solutions that have high visibility within the ad products organization. You should be an autonomous self-starter who thrives on implementing creative approaches and dealing with the intricate complexity of large data sets. You should love partnering with internal tech teams to build a robust data engineering platform. You should be analytical, creative, and passionate about building and maintaining best-in-class data infrastructures.

Key functions of this role:
Develop in-depth knowledge of data systems spanning Amazon retail, Sales CRM and marketing systems, and ad serving platforms.
Use your knowledge to architect data warehousing and BI solutions that solve problems that cut across Amazon business functions including Sales, Marketing, and Finance.
Interface with business customers, gathering requirements and delivering complete Data Engineering, Data Warehousing, and BI solutions.
Interface with other technology teams to extract, transform, and load data from a wide variety of data sources using SQL (Redshift, Oracle) and ability to use a major programming (e.g. Java/C) and/or a scripting language (Perl, Unix shell) to process data for modeling
Act as a product owner: leading customer utilization research projects to better understand how your customers are using your product.
Recognize and adopt best practices in reporting and analysis: data integrity, test design, analysis, validation, and documentation.
Preferred Qualifications
Master's degree in Engineering or Math/Statistics/Finance or related discipline
Experience building/operating highly available, distributed systems of data extraction, ingestion, and processing of large data sets
Experience leading large-scale data warehousing and analytics projects, including using AWS technologies  Redshift, S3, EC2, Data-pipeline and other big data technologies
Experience providing technical leadership and mentor other engineers for the best practices on the data engineering space

At HP, the future is yours to create!  HP Marketing Data Sciences is a cutting-edge team with the agility of a startup and the depth of a Fortune-500 company with a storied history of innovation going back to 1939. In our team, you will play the role of a leader and subject matter expert in the digital marketing transformation through our Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence and Data Science capability.  We are looking for visionaries, like you, who are ready to make a purposeful impact on the way the world works.  You will be responsible for managing junior-level data scientists/analysts and providing guidance to the team in building customer profiles, developing predictive models, and developing segmentation approaches to enable the planning and execution of marketing campaigns. You will also be expected to be able to conduct analysis and develop algorithms and procedures, particularly for demonstrating new approaches. Additionally, you will collaborate with partners in the business unit marketing, insights, and measurement organizations on specific analytics projects to improve business processes. You will report to Global Head of Marketing Data Sciences.  Are you a high-performer? We are looking for an individual with:  MS/PHD in Computer Science, Engineering, Math, Statistics or related field  8-10 years of experience in data science, customer insights and marketing analytics program management and operations with a leading e-commerce player  Advanced statistics background for analytical positions preferred (advanced degree preferred) with research and statistical focus background for analytics roles.  In-depth hands-on experience in BI and Analytics tools like R, SAS, SPSS, Tableau etc, SQL and databases like Vertica/Redshift/Teradata.  Expert knowledge of marketing principles, practices, tactics and tools.  Expert in data manipulation and analysis techniques; comfortable using very containing both structured and unstructured data  Experience in the Digital Marketing space and web analytics. Knowledge of media data.  Experience in Data Architecture / Data Analysis / Database programing.  Experience in use of Big Data technologies (e.g. Hadoop, Hive, Scala, Pig, etc.), AWS technologies and services  In-depth knowledge in digital marketing platforms (DMP and DSPs) and media data.  Experience in Marketing systems such as MRM or CRM applications.  In-depth knowledge of Marketing fundamentals, lifecycle, marketing mix and knowledge management.  Excellent written/oral communication and interpersonal skills; ability to build, manage and influence direct reports and virtual teams.  Strong influencing, consensus-building and conflict resolution skills.  Job Duties  Direct/supervise the execution of marketing programs against metrics and goals.  Direct/supervise the management of marketing assets and perform closed-loop analysis to drive continuous improvements to marketing efficiency and effectiveness.  Integrate disparate datasets, analyze large volume of datasets to draw relevant business conclusions  Direct the development of value-added business performance analytics and optimization recommendations that enable continuous improvement across the operations of field marketing and demand generation.  Automate data load and transformation processes and operationalize models. Improve data availability.  Identify data problems and automate the corrective action  Analyze data collected from various sources to measure campaign performance and identify opportunities to improve Campaign KPI measurement framework  Lead the implementation of marketing process and tools such as marketing resource management (MRM), customer relationship management (CRM) and customer knowledge management (CKM).  Manage the integration and utilization of new campaign management and other MPM tools, lead the development of training and research materials and related processes and tools.  Build executive presentation for business review  Typically hire/manage/develop Entry, Intermediate and/or Specialist-level ICs.
